right sorry um yeah so so one of the important functions of of the tsse is facilitating
governance for some of the projects within whoops within the cncf so a lot
of people think governance is just extra paperwork or busy work that gets in the way of doing the real work on the
project but this isn't true of good governance which is really about setting expectations and getting all of the
various people within your community collaborating together and ultimately the focus of open source project
governance is on the people the roles we play our responsibilities how we make
decisions and what we should expect from each other as part of participating in the community having clear rules about
how collaboration occurs how decisions are made and what types of contributions are in or out of scope helps community
members make contributions that are likely to get accepted and be embraced by the project and this helps avoid
wasting maintainers time right with contributions that just aren't aligned with project a healthy project with
clear governance helps set your project up for future growth and long-term success now the tricky thing about
governance is that it has to be proactive the time to work on governance
is when things are going really well if you wait until there's a crisis of some
sort within your community it's too late you're not going to have the processes in place for dealing with that crisis
and when a project is in crisis it's going to be very very difficult to get people to come to an agreement on making
changes or additions to the governance so in general we recommend for cncf projects you start with the simplest
possible governance model and only move to something more complicated when your project evolves to the point where that
complexity is actually needed because otherwise you introduce a lot of overhead a lot of extra work and you
spend time on governance instead of spending time on project development and projects do evolve over time and we
expect that cncf projects will evolve their governance along with their
project now when it comes time for your project to undergo a governance review
it will be a much easier process if you've based your project governance on
one of our templates and use our guides to develop your governance please please please do
not just pick your favorite random cncf project and base your project governance on that project some projects have
better governance than others and because each project is a little different what you need from your
governance model will be different than what another project needs so most cncf projects start with
what we call the maintainer council model which of course we have a template for and this is the simplest form of
governance and this is the one we recommend for most cncf projects so this is where maintainers get to make the
decisions in the project Often by consensus but there's usually also a provision for voting in certain
cases and as projects become larger and more complex you might need to move to
one of our other governance models or you might not we have a template for projects that
are made up of many different sub projects um which is where you need a
multi-level structure where sub project leadership kind of flows up to overall project leadership but this is a really
complex model and it's really only recommended in rare cases for projects that have a lot of semi-autonomous
projects underneath them we also have a template for elected steering committees but again this adds a lot of complexity
and we really only recommend it for projects that have maybe many different groups with competing priorities or
maybe a very large number of maintainers who can easily reach consensus quickly
or when there's a need to enforce something like employer representation limits and again we recommend using the
simplest possible governance model that you can now this is just a rough summary of
the governance requirements it's not a complete list so you want to look at the full requirements in the application and
moving levels guides the One requirement across all levels is the adoption of the cncf code of
conduct um and we while we don't require a governance model for sandbox projects
it's recommended to have at least something lightweight um and having thought through through and implemented some
governance for your sandbox project uh will make your sandbox application a lot stronger incubation is where we actually
start requiring governance at a minimum you need to have an accurate and complete list of current current
maintainers and those maintainers should be active in your project the number of maintainers should also be appropriate
for the size and scope of the project that you're working on we also look at
whether the documented governance is actually reflected in the reality of how your project operates including
ownership and responsibilities in GitHub to match what the project is documented there's also a long list of suggested
but not required things for governance and most if not all of them are probably still worth doing at the incubating
level and it will make your application to move to incubating a lot stronger now at the graduating level
there are extensive governance requirements so I'm not going to be able to cover them all here but using one of
our governance templates will help you meet those requirements and some of the critical requirements are that the
governance is clear discoverable and vendor neutral with
documented processes for project decision- making including how people are selected for leadership positions
And The Links at the bottom of the slide have loads more details about the requirements and the slides are already

help project grow and improve so keep this in mind when you're going through the review process our goal is to use
these reviews to make cncf projects even better over time so we're not trying to
trick you or punish you for not having absolutely perfect governance as I
mentioned on the last slide your governance review is likely to be easier if you followed one of our templates but
we can do the governance review even if you haven't it might just take a little bit
longer if you haven't followed one of the templates and we have an issue template linked at the bottom of the slide that you can

basic information about your project to help the reviewers find more details when we ask questions it also has a
section for governance model details so this is where you tell us which template you used any places where you deviated
from the template or if you have something more custom and didn't use a template you'll describe it in that section
and then we ask for links to your governance documents which can be one single big big file or multiple
documents we also want to know how you've been executing on your governance so while having documented governance is
important you also need to follow those processes in your project so we ask for examples of
execution of the governance so that could include things like voting on something or promoting a contributor
maybe demoing a maintainer or you know a few other other things and as I mentioned before we expect
governance to evolve over the Project's lifespan so it's expected that changes will occur over the projects life and
such changes are iterative tested adjusted and if there are any major
milestones in the Project's governance over time we'll ask you to describe those as well so finally then we ask a
few questions to better understand whether you're looking for feedback or know of any areas that you're already
planning to improve your governance now now I'll will give you just one one quick example um in the

good example and this review was conducted as part of their application to move from incubating to graduated
which is a pretty uh common time for a governance review and as I mentioned earlier the expectations for governance
at the graduated level are pretty high so this is an important time for the review now the Dapper project governance
was already closely aligned with our steering committee template which made the governance review fairly
straightforward compared to projects that maybe aren't as aligned with the template and there were a few things
that stood out in the Dapper governance they have a really detailed definition of the community manager role along with
excellent contributor docs to help it make the project more accessible to new contributors they have good vendor
neutrality with no one company being over represented which is another thing we look closely at especially for projects
applying for graduation and they also follow good security practices um for
securing access to the Project's resources now almost every project does have areas where they can be improved
which in this case were relatively minor and non-blocking for graduation so for
example they could use some GitHub tooling that might make it easier um to

so then we we start to move on to day one so day one incubation and there's a
kind of a a little bit of a kind of a I I work um tag with tag Network in about
the last 12 months I've done maybe eight sandbox
reviews one incubation review or one incubation review has been started now
the the kind of the differences an incubation review is not massively overwhelming but we kind of start to
look at different factors starting to move on to the thought about getting things production ready or getting
things more in in self- sustainability and we cover Three core sections when
looking at an incubation review and that is that configuration and activation enablement roll back and an upgrade and
roll back planning so kind of dig into those in depth so the question around
configuration and activation is predominantly what does configuration and activation look like so you know the
question you ask is well why is that important and and the reason that it's important is that in configuration and
activation is generally the the end user's first interaction with your project so they've spent the time to do
the due diligence to understand what the project does and that they want to try it out the next step along that process
is to go and do it to install it on a cluster and configuration and activation
have a a huge impact on the success of that step and then obviously this to you
as a project maintainer why that's important well it it affects the the drop off it affects the adoptability
so we want to to kind of start seeing good user experience or just thought
around config and activation because as a project matures that you know that the tolerance
of a Sandbox project people are are quite tolerant to what they understand that it's it's sort of a a smaller um
project it might have less maintainers and things might be a little bit rough around the edges as developing but once
you start getting to incubation there's a kind of an expectation that has has also
grown so then around that kind of theme we're also looking at things like
enablement and roll back so how can it be enabled so that you know what is the ease of getting it into your cluster but
also how can it be disabled um how does the kind of the
project changes any behavior on the cluster so is is there an impact of the software that I'm installing on my
cluster cluster that that could have a a KnockOn effect of of other projects how do you test that that sort
of an enablement so that it is a a smooth process that factors into things like upgrades and and such and does it
also clean up any resources now as as a project maintainer you would hope that I'm never going to want to to uninstall
your project and and that's absolutely right but the key thing is that you've got to think about around that is that
as if I'm working for an organization I might factor in in the the kind of the
cleanup or the removal process as part of my evaluation so if you don't have those things considered then you know I
might not actually sort of adopt your project in the first place so there's a number of factors you've got to think about why this is actually
important and then we have a a huge list of questions when it comes down to roll
back and planning but we're you know we're predominantly on the the theme of
productionizing things ready for for graduation so you're looking at things like what is the sort of the you know
compatibility with infrastructure have you kind of tested and evaluated different different sort of
configurations there um how does roll back look like what is the upgrade process are you kind of notifying your
the end users of of updates for Alphas or betas or or even just kind of stable
Channel updates and and all of those kind of things are tying into that just getting
ready to move on to the next stage and and the the TLC reviewer will be kind of
looking at a number of factors when they're considering your your incubation application and they're looking at things like adoptability usability
transparency supportability and supportability for you is also the key
thing so with good user experience with a good documentation with easy installation and roll back procedures
